title: 107_s689
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Governors Island Preservation Act of 2001". Congress finds that in August 1776, Governors Island fortifications provided cover for George Washington's Continental Army during the Battle of Long Island. New York ceded control of the island to the Federal Government in 1800 for defense purposes. During the War of 1812, Castle Williams and the Southwest Battery deterred a British attack on New York City. In 1901, fill from the Lexington Avenue Subway excavation was used on the island. Governors Island's history includes its role in the Civil War, World War I, and World War II, serving the United States Army until 1966. In 1966, the Army relocated, and the United States Coast Guard took over, playing a key role in the Coast Guard's Atlantic coast efforts for 30 years. The Coast Guard ceased operations at Governors Island in 1997, leaving 225 buildings unoccupied and exposed to New York Harbor's elements. Castle Williams is named after Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Williams, who built the fort, and Fort Jay is named after John Jay. The Governors Island National Monument, established in 2001, includes Castle Williams and Fort Jay. The State of New York and the city of New York have agreed on a redevelopment plan for the island. The Governors Island National Monument, established in 2001, includes Castle Williams and Fort Jay. The State of New York and the city of New York have agreed on a redevelopment plan for the island. The Act aims to ensure public access, preserve historic structures, involve local officials and community organizations, and provide educational, recreational, and cultural opportunities on Governors Island. The Act aims to provide public access to Governors Island and its National Monument, open park space, recreational resources, and views of New York Harbor. It also aims to return property to the State of New York and ensure the Secretary retains rights to operate the National Monument. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Administrator - Administrator of General Services.
(2) City - City of New York.
(3) Corporation - Governors Island Redevelopment Corporation, subsidiary of Empire State Development Corporation.
(4) Management plan - plan prepared under section 4(c).
(5) Monument - Governors Island National Monument established by Presidential Proclamation 7402.
(6) Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
(7) State - State of New York. SEC. 4. GOVERNORS ISLAND NATIONAL MONUMENT. The Administrator shall transfer administrative jurisdiction and management of the Monument to the Secretary within 180 days of enactment. The Monument will be administered by the Secretary in accordance with relevant laws, including those applicable to the National Park System. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with interested entities for the preservation, development, and interpretation of the Monument. Interpretive services and signage may be provided in the Governors Island National Historic Landmark District with the agreement of the Corporation. The Secretary will prepare a management plan for the Monument within 3 years, in consultation with the Corporation and other entities, in accordance with applicable laws. Upon completion, the plan will be submitted to relevant parties. The Secretary will submit the management plan to the House Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. The Administrator will reserve access rights for maintenance and public enjoyment of the Monument, as well as for aids to navigation on Governors Island. Utilities provision and access will be a condition of the conveyance. The Monument's conveyance under section 5 requires compliance with state public service law and an agreement between the Secretary and the Corporation. The Administrator must reserve necessary buildings for the Monument's operation and maintenance, subject to an agreement. Appropriations are authorized for annual operation and maintenance. SEC. 5. CONVEYANCE OF GOVERNORS ISLAND. The Administrator shall convey Governors Island to the State of New York, excluding the Monument, for no consideration. Upon conveyance of Governors Island to the State of New York, the use of the land must comply with specific regulations and guidelines outlined in the Governors Island Preservation and Design Manual, approved by the Administrator, State, and City.
